/COMMIT_MSG.message: Missed this. Will catch next time I need to respin

Maybe, but we don't know, and it's a big world out there with people that have lots of pets they don't like to touch, so this kind of logic isn't really something we should consider OK when we have mechanisms in place to detect and move the data forward, like the online_data_migrations CLI. If all you'd need to do is query the cell db for a certain format, and if found run it through the object and save it back, then that seems pretty easy and avoids breaking someone on upgrade.

Um, what? I think our upgrades were likely better back then :)

IMHO, it's not okay to make this change until you've put an online migration into place for a while. Technically a blocker migration would be called for here, but it would be kind of expensive since it needs to do an in-text-field search.

> so this kind of logic isn't really something we should consider OK when we have mechanisms in place to detect and move the data forward, like the online_data_migrations CLI.

Right. It's also not okay because people may be doing an FFU to blow past a bunch of runtime code, everything looked good (i.e. no complaints) and yet for some reason all of one kind of their instances are crashing on load without so much as an exception handler to explain why.

nova/objects/compute_node.py.message:
Typically when we do these for things that can also migrate on lazy-load we use the lazy-load routines themselves here instead of replicating it. Why is this not doing that? Like, we'll have something like:

 things = list_things_to_convert()
 for thing in things:
     obj = load_thing()
     obj.save()

That also helps to make sure we're not migrating things slightly differently here vs. on lazy load at runtime. Sometimes we *only* migrate things in a migration, but the numa objects can migrate themselves on load. Why not use that pattern here?
Oh, good idea. Don't know why I didn't do that initially.

I really wish this didn't exist. We've had objects in the past that had non-serialized-object to_json type methods. This one is doing the right thing, but I'd really rather this just do the obj_to_primitive() right here to make it clear that we're getting the properly-serialized version.
This kind of substring search in SQL is going to be super slow, no? I guess since we're not expecting thousands of compute nodes, it's probably not a big deal?

Yeah - so both .contains() and .startswith() produce LIKE statements AFAICT [1] [2], the difference being the wildcard. And while the latter should be faster [3], I *think* that assumes an index on the column, which we don't have in this case, right?

I feel like we're speculating out of ignorance here, I'd like an ORM/SQL expert to set us straight.

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/core/sqlelement.html#sqlalchemy.sql.operators.ColumnOperators.contains
[2] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/core/sqlelement.html#sqlalchemy.sql.operators.ColumnOperators.startswith
[3] https://use-the-index-luke.com/sql/where-clause/searching-for-ranges/like-performance-tuning

Fair point. Switched to 'startswith', which seems to perform much better for indexed rows at least [1]

[1] https://stackoverflow.com/q/2481528/

nova/objects/instance.py.message: Ditto, re: slowness, except in this case we're potentially looking at thousands (millions?) of instances...

nova/objects/instance_numa.py.message: Actually, this can go as well. Good spot.
why can we get rid of this?

The only reason 'nova_object.name' wouldn't exist is if this wasn't a versioned object. As noted in the commit message, we haven't used non-versioned objects for this since before Mitaka, and, since then, any time we've pulled instances from the database we have been converting them to versioned objects (the '_from_dict' function) and saving them back in the new format. As such, this is a no-op nowadays and has been for some time.

Have you done an online migration to move everyone? It is very likely people still have instances that were created before mitaka, and potentially unchanged since then. I'm not sure I see where the post-conversion save would be, except for just the case where the instance gets saved because of some other operation.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I guess the builds are performed whenever the previous run failed, but should this be configurable? For example:

 * Change A updates zookeeper image for TLS support
 * Change B updates zuul deployment to setup TLS

Running B deployment without a successful A deployment might results in an unstable result.

That would be unfortunate, but I don't think it's something we can address in this manager (I don't think we're going to want to un-merge a change).  I could see a deployer setting a flag though to stop further processing.  That could be done on an external system, or we could expose that in Zuul to allow the pipeline to be disabled.  But let's leave that for a further enhancement.

With regards to adding a flag to customize how `serial` behave in case of failure, then perhaps we could add a flag to customize how `supercedent` behave when there are running build and make it behave like the proposed `serial` manager. I don't mind either way though.
How is the sequence enforced? Could this be affected by out-of-order event from the review system? And if so, shouldn't the manager ensure that the build order match the change git reference order?

It's the order of events.  They won't be out of order with an event-triggered system like gerrit stream-events or github, but could happen with polling (like gerrit checks).  Given that we want this to be a change-based pipeline, I'm not sure the pipeline is well-placed to determine the order in the git repo.  It might be best for us to try to make sure the drivers report events in the correct order.

distributedcloud/dcmanager/tests/unit/ap.message: Also verify that mock_upload_files was called with the expected values.
As per discussion, we will be adding this test at a later time.

One of the parameter types for mock_upload_files.assert_called_with() is FieldStorage(name, filename).
I created a FieldStorage(name, filename) object for the test, using 'content-disposition' header.
However, the name and filename have to be either ascii or utf8, it can not be ascii name and utf8 filename.

The upload_files parameter in the post request, which is a list of (fieldname, filename, file_content),
is converted to list of FieldStorage(name, filename) internally, the name must be ascii and file name is encoded to utf8.

As a result, the following assertion error is encountered:
if the test uses ascii:
Expected call: _upload_files('/opt/platform/deploy/TEST.SW.VERSION', 'deploy_chart', FieldStorage('deploy_chart', 'deploy_chart_fake'), True)
Actual call:   _upload_files('/opt/platform/deploy/TEST.SW.VERSION', 'deploy_chart', FieldStorage('deploy_chart', u'deploy_chart_fake'), True)

if the test uses utf8:
Expected call: _upload_files('/opt/platform/deploy/TEST.SW.VERSION', 'deploy_chart', FieldStorage(u'deploy_chart', u'deploy_chart_fake'), True)
Actual call:   _upload_files('/opt/platform/deploy/TEST.SW.VERSION', 'deploy_chart', FieldStorage('deploy_chart', u'deploy_chart_fake'), True)


Do you have any suggestions which will help me to resolve this unit test issue?

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_systemd_wr.message:
Is there a reason not to do this in a loop? 

Something to think about that is related:
if we have to do a wrapper->path notification->oneshot for every neutron sidecar it might take a very long time for controllers with a lot of routers, subnets, whatever, to come up into a functional state on a restart. Also besides rebooting a controller, failover with HA routers might result in a lot of sidecars getting started when a failover occurs. It would be better to avoid any excessive performance regressions.

note, the sync service is a singleton process, there is no way to have a few running. Either by the original design or the proposed changes for simple service or this one. So it's performance will be still limited to the time it takes to process a single container. I don't think this can be changed without reworking the thing completely and allowing multiple sync services firing off containers from individual job files...

the loop has been moved to the callers (wrappers) side instead. This oneshot fires off by any path trigger. And the likely reason for it being triggered is a job waiting to be picked up from the pipe. So that's triggering ensures a loop for calling the sync, not the sync running a loop. If you think such strictly serializable processing of commands would be slow, let's think of multiple pipes and passing in the pipe name for the sync as well.

Yeah we are serialized there. The only thing we can win is a reduction in context switches to process a set workload. What we have here is analogous to a bunch of fixed function worker threads on an assembly line with a single workqueue. Ideally we'd get some scale/perf testing on this stuff. We might find that it doesn't practically impact anything - on the other hand it might end up being completely unusable.

I don't think there is any reason to wait for the lock.  Having a lock on the service_wrapper side makes sense to ensure there is not write contention.  But since the sync script is a singleton it's fine for the sync script to just read from the fifo.  The 'read' will wait for an end of line before proceeding.  If we have a hundred haproxy sidecars that need to start then blocking on the lock will really exacerbate things.  Also, ten seconds is a reeeeeally long time to wait here if we are going to do tons of spawning.
Thank you, well spotted!

This likely won't fix the issue because I believe the fact that the sync scripts exit if they can't lock is the problem.  If we end up with multiple syncs running at the same time but take too long, then the subsequent syncs may exit without ever being rerun so we end up with data pending that won't be picked up until another writer kicks off a script at some point.

We probably need a real service running to monitor the queue and launch things as necessary.  At this time we should just revert and investigate a different solution.

Alex, please keep in mind that sync script uses locks as of its day 1. So normally there is no situations possible when 
"multiple syncs running", unless locking fails its very goal due to subtle corner cases.

Do you have a confirmation for the 10sec timeout on locking being the root cause of the subject issue?

To my understanding, the root cause is a loop in the sync service and the path unit merging update events. That ends up in pending jobs remaining "merged" truncated off the jobs file.

neat! Is there a condition where the pipe might become full if there isn't a reader or we aren't reading fast enough?  Is there possibility of a partial write if the pipe is full? If so, maybe the proper thing to do is find out if neutron does some useful error handling and return an error.

So according to http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/pipe.7.html the cap is at least a 65k. I'm not sure if that would be sufficient. Handling corner cases may be wanted indeed. On the bright side, I beleive "an application should be designed so that a reading processconsumes data as soon as it is available" perfectly fits here! :)
Good question. To my naïve understanding, there is no limits for FIFO pipes for its "buffering" capacity nor for its max size since those are just files?..
So IIUC, the purpose here is to check if something is there, if so, try replaying it back into the pipe to trigger the systemd.path notification?
yes, this busy loop ensures no events will be missed if the path unit merges notifications.
Technically this may be a non-blocking read as well. The resulting shortest possible wrapper execution time will become less than a 1s. As is, that's a 1s minimum exec time.
during this window, any other instantiated wrapper may "capture the flag" allowing this one to exit.
while adding to this shared file w/o lockin it doesn't look perfectly safe for concurrent wrappers, I hope this is fine cuz likely neing an extremely rare path?..

Since the dnsmasq man page says:

  --test Read and syntax check configuration file(s). Exit with code 0 if

specs/untargeted/volume-record-failure-i.message: I think this feature doesnot need the tempest tests.

Here should add a new microversion to list/show volume(s) details, so you should description the change of these APIs:

[1] List accessible volumes with details https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=#list-accessible-volumes-with-details

[2] Show a volume’s details https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=#show-a-volume-s-details
We do kind-of have a security impact here as it is exposing failure details to the end user.  This would have previously been limited to the administrator.
This spec doesn't explain why you can't do this with user messages already.

Yes, this function is actually to help the user to display the log information, so as to avoid manually looking for the log, which is very troublesome in the multi-node environment,
Here, because the detail is limited to 255 characters, you only see driver.extend_volume(). If you increase the length limit, you can display the driver file
More details of the error location, as in the log.This will be more detailed than the user message.Of course, I have also considered how to use the user message framework
Message and detail are populated automatically without having to add them to the message_field manually.

Eric has a good point here.  He raised it earlier, and you replied that the problem is that current user messages, which are designed to be displayed to the end user, don't provide enough information.  But looking at the example you give at line 93, the stack trace really doesn't provide any more information than the message.  Message is: driver failed to extend volume.  Trace is the call to driver.extend_volume().  What the person troubleshooting this needs to do is look at the backend and see what's up, and this stack trace doesn't really help in that regard.

So I'm back to thinking that we should stick with user messages here.  I'm not saying that user messages couldn't be improved, just that you should reconsider using that framework for this proposal -- or explain clearly why they are insufficient.  Seems to me that a combination of user messages + logstash gets you everything you need here.

It now appears that the only advantage of this framework is that it automatically validates message and stack messages, unlike the user message, which needs to be added manually, when you need to specify a new exception.
We need to be clear about who this is: since we're only allowing an admin to see this, we're talking about an *operator* here.
yes, it means admin user only.
Where is this coming from? Will it be the exception message or something else?

This functionality constructs a function decorator that extracts try...except error of the decorated function as message(like line 95) and captures the error stack as the details.
This is why the framework does not need to add messages manually.

I just want to be clear here.  Is your proposal that only an administrator will see the 'fault' element in the response?   (Just want to be clear that we're not talking about displaying 'fault' to end user, but only include the 'details' field for administrators.)
yes,only admin will see fault element.
Why do this, if we are only going to display the most recent?
It can be used as a basis for a subsequent feature extension, such as viewing error history.

An alternative I'd like you to address is using something like Logstash to collate and index the logs from all the cinder nodes.  I imagine most large deployments are doing that already, and so the info in the volume_faults table is going to be redundant.  Additionally, collating the logs allows you get contextual information about what's been happening with the particular volume you're interested in (that is, you have more information that just the last bad thing that happened to this volume), and also to determine whether other volumes are experiencing similar errors.
The alternative is the existing user messages functionality, which is probably what should be used instead of adding this framework.

This role is ran at least twice, first it's supposed to be run to generate saved_state.json only and then again to run --dry-run or actual cleanup. It's due to the reason that a user essentially runs tempest in between those two runs because this role doesn't run tempest, it runs only 'tempest cleanup'.


This role can be used by anyone and it's purpose is to run 'tempest cleanup'. It's documented in the role README that saved_state should be generated prior actual cleanup. 
The role is controlled by variables, if init_saved_state is true, only --init-saved-state is executed (so it'll generate saved_state.json), the same for --dry-run, if none of the variables is defined (therefore both of them are by default false) it makes sense that 'tempest cleanup' is run as the role is called tempest-cleanup - me as a role user would definitely expect that if I run it as is (without specifying other variables) it would run the cleanup.


In order to provide a safe usage in the gates, we'll use pre_cleanup and cleanup variables within devstack-tempest.yaml playbook as you suggested so that the usage of the role is clear to everyone whose job inherits from devstack-tempest one.

nit: Since "code" (as in source code) is an uncountable noun in English you would consider it singular so the properly agreeing words would be "to allow code ... if it matches".

nit: I would use a colon here; you can use a colon to connect two sentences when the second sentence summarizes, sharpens, or explains the first

No, you are using a semicolon (;) which connects two complete sentences that are independent from each other; the colon (:) connects two sentences when the latter depends on or is tightly related to the former.

I would remove the entire concept of a secondary goal here as it is misleading.  I would suggest wording something like this: "Replacing instances of oslo.rootwrap usage requires more than just a drop-in replacement.
